title: Hoogeveen
text:
Hoogeveen (; or " 't Oveine") is a <a href="Municipalities%20of%20the%20Netherlands">municipality</a> and a <a href="town">town</a> in the northeastern <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>. 
Population centres.
<a href="Elim%2C%20Drenthe">Elim</a>, <a href="Fluitenberg">Fluitenberg</a>, Hoogeveen and <a href="Noordscheschut">Noordscheschut</a>, which still have the canals which used to be throughout the town. Other villages of the town are <a href="Hollandscheveld">Hollandscheveld</a>, <a href="Nieuw%20Moscou">Nieuw Moscou</a>, <a href="Nieuweroord">Nieuweroord</a>, <a href="Nieuwlande">Nieuwlande</a>, <a href="Pesse">Pesse</a>, <a href="Stuifzand">Stuifzand</a> and <a href="Tiendeveen">Tiendeveen</a>.
History.
Hoogeveen dates its history to 20 December 1625, when <a href="Roelof%20van%20Echten">Roelof van Echten</a> bought a large tract of <a href="peat">peat</a> land from farmers of the district with the plan to harvest its peat. One old map of the area called it "Locus Deserta Atque ob Multos Paludes Invia", a deserted and impenetrable place of many swamps. Hoogeveen itself was established in 1636 by Peter Joostens Warmont and Johan van der Meer.
Its <a href="coat%20of%20arms">coat of arms</a>, granted 10 November 1819, is white, with a pile of peat covered in straw in the center and <a href="beehive">beehive</a>s on each side, representing the town's first two major industries.
<a href="Vincent%20van%20Gogh">Vincent van Gogh</a> visited the area in the fall of 1883.
In the second half of the 1960s, Hoogeveen was the fastest growing town in the Netherlands. Its rapid growth during that period led its city council to fill in most of the town's <a href="canal">canal</a>s, canals dug in the area's early days when it was a prime source of peat.
Access to the town is provided by the A28 (<a href="Utrecht%20%28province%29">Utrecht</a> - <a href="Groningen%20%28province%29">Groningen</a>) highway, the N/A37 (Hoogeveen - <a href="Germany">Germany</a>), and the Western Cities - Groningen <a href="Train%20routes%20in%20the%20Netherlands">railway</a>.
The then recognized oldest person in the world, <a href="Hendrikje%20van%20Andel-Schipper">Hendrikje van Andel-Schipper</a>, lived in Hoogeveen until her death in August 2005, two months after her 115th birthday.
Hoogeveen also has a small <a href="Hoogeveen%20Airport">airport</a> that attracts some tourism. Since 1997 the Hoogeveen Chess Tournament has been organized here.
Transport.
Railway Station: <a href="Hoogeveen%20railway%20station">Hoogeveen</a>
International relations.
Twin towns — Sister cities.
Hoogeveen is <a href="Twin%20towns%20and%20sister%20cities">twinned</a> with:
